member.name: T:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ExtensionName
member.summary: The names of agreed extensions to WITSML. This list may be locally extended but it is recommended that new names be approved by the WITSML SIG before use. Each standard name must define its data type. For string types, the maximum length must be defined in number of characters. For measures, the expected measure class must be defined.

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.ExtensionDataEnumValue.#ctor
member.summary: Protected constructor, should always pass in "name"

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.ExtensionDataEnumValue.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.ExtensionDataEnumValue.ExtensionDataType
member.summary: For extensions, the underlying data type of the value.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.ExtensionDataEnumValue.ExtensionMaximumSize
member.summary: For extensions, the maximum number of charactetrs in a string value.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.ExtensionDataEnumValue.ExtensionMeasureClass
member.summary: For extensions, defines the measure class associated with the temm. This controls the allowed units of measure. If this is specified then the value must be defined with a unit of measure.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.ExtensionDataEnumValue.ExtensionPath
member.summary: For extensions, defines the path to the allowed location in the schema where the extension is allowed. This should begin at the singular object level (e.g., "/well/commonData/extension"). A relative location will allow it in any object (i.e., ".//commonData/extension"). A relative location within the object will allow it at any location within that object (e.g., "/opsReport//commonData/extension").

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ExtensionName.#ctor
member.summary: Protected constructor, should always pass in "name"

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ExtensionName.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ExtensionName.GetList
member.summary: Retrieves the complete list of ExtensionNames

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ExtensionName.Dummyexamplestring
member.summary: This is an example for the purpose of demonstrating the capabilities. This name should not be used and can be removed from a production file. It describes a string of maximum length of 64 characters which can be used in the commonData of any object. The semantics of the name would be defined in this description field.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ExtensionName.Dummyexamplemeasure
member.summary: This is an example for the purpose of demonstrating the capabilities. This name should not be used and can be removed from a production file. It describes a length measure which can only be specified in the commonData of the well and wellbore objects. The semantics of the name would be defined in this description field. The extensionMeasureClass constrains the allowed units of measure for each value. The extensionDataType value of double constrains the size of each value.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ExtensionName.Dummyexampledatetime
member.summary: This is an example for the purpose of demonstrating the capabilities. This name should not be used and can be removed from a production file. It describes a dateTime value which can be specified anywhere in the tubular object. The semantics of the name would be defined in this description field.

member.name: T:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType
member.summary: These values represent the lithological terminology used in descriptions of rock cuttings in mud logs.

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.#ctor
member.summary: Protected constructor, should always pass in "name"

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.GetList
member.summary: Retrieves the complete list of LithologyTypes

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.AlkaliFeldsparRhyolite
member.summary: Rhyolitoid in which the ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is less than 0.1. QAPF field 2. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.AlkaliOlivineBasalt
member.summary: Alkali olivine basalt is silica-undersaturated, characterized by the absence of orthopyroxene, absence of quartz, presence of olivine, and typically contains some feldspathoid mineral, alkali feldspar or phlogopite in the groundmass. Feldspar phenocrysts typically are labradorite to andesine in composition. Augite is rich in titanium compared to augite in tholeiitic basalt. Alkali olivine basalt is relatively rich in sodium. Carmichael, I.S. Turner, F.J., Verhoogen, John, 1974, Igneous petrology: New York, McGraw HIll Book Co., p.42-43.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Amphibolite
member.summary: Metamorphic rock mainly consisting of green, brown or black amphibole and plagioclase (including albite), which combined form 75 percent or more of the rock, and both of which are present as major constituents. The amphibole constitutes 50 percent or more of the total mafic constituents and is present in an amount of 30 percent or more; other common minerals include quartz, clinopyroxene, garnet, epidote-group minerals, biotite, titanite and scapolite. Coutinho et al. 2007, IUGS SCMR chapter 8.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Andesite
member.summary: Fine-grained igneous rock with less than 20 percent quartz and less than 10 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction, in which the ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is greater 0.65. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 or chemically in TAS field O2 as andesite. Basalt and andesite, which share the same QAPF fields, are distinguished chemically based on silica content, with basalt defined to contain less than 52 weight percent silica. If chemical data are not available, the color index is used to distinguish the categories, with basalt defined to contain greater than 35 percent mafic minerals by volume or greater than 40 percent mafic minerals by weight. Typically consists of plagioclase (frequently zoned from labradorite to oligoclase), pyroxene, hornblende and/or biotite. Fine grained equivalent of dioritic rock. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Anhydrite
member.summary: Evaporite composed of at least 50 percent anhydrite. OneGeology / WITSML

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.AnorthositicRock
member.summary: Leucocratic phaneritic crystalline igneous rock consisting essentially of plagioclase, often with small amounts of pyroxene. By definition, colour index M is less than 10, and plagiclase to total feldspar ratio is greater than 0.9. Less than 20 percent quartz and less than 10 percent feldspathoid in the QAPF fraction. QAPF field 10, 10*, and 10'. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Anthracite
member.summary: Coal that has vitrinite mean random reflectance greater than 2.0 percent (determined in conformance with ISO 7404-5). Less than 12-14 percent volatiles (dry, ash free), greater than 91 percent fixed carbon (dry, ash free basis). The highest rank coal; very hard, glossy, black, with semimetallic luster, semi conchoidal fracture. Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp; see also Neuendorf et al. 2005

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Aplite
member.summary: Light coloured crystalline rock, characterized by a fine grained allotriomorphic-granular (aplitic, saccharoidal or xenomorphic) texture; typically granitic composition, consisting of quartz, alkali feldspar and sodic plagioclase. Neuendorf et al 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Arenite
member.summary: Clastic sandstone that contains less than 10 percent matrix. Matrix is mud-size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products) of detrital or diagenetic nature. Pettijohn, Potter, Siever, 1972, Sand and Sandstone: New York, Springer Verlag, 681 p. WITSML note: In drill cuttings there is a tendancy for grains to break apart, and loose the matrix, so frequently Sandstone is used rather then Arenite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Arkose
member.summary: An indurated arenaceous deposit consisting chiefly of quartz and feldspar (greater than 25%).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Basalt
member.summary: Fine-grained or porphyritic igneous rock with less than 20 percent quartz, and less than 10 percent feldspathoid minerals, in which the ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is greater 0.65. Typically composed of calcic plagioclase and clinopyroxene; phenocrysts typically include one or more of calcic plagioclase, clinopyroxene, orthopyroxene, and olivine. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 or chemically in TAS field B as basalt. Basalt and andesite are distinguished chemically based on silica content, with basalt defined to contain less than 52 weight percent silica. If chemical data are not available, the color index is used to distinguish the categories, with basalt defined to contain greater than 35 percent mafic minerals by volume or greater than 40 percent mafic minerals by weight. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Basanite
member.summary: Tephritoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.9, and contains more than 10 percent normative (CIPW) olivine. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Bauxite
member.summary: Highly aluminous material containing abundant aluminium hydroxides (gibbsite, less commonly boehmite, diaspore) and aluminium-substituted iron oxides or hydroxides and generally minor or negligible kaolin minerals; may contain up to 20 percent quartz. Commonly has a pisolitic or nodular texture, and may be cemented. Eggleton 2001.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.BituminousCoal
member.summary: Coal that has vitrinite mean random reflectance greater than 0.6 percent and less than 2.0 percent (determined in conformance with ISO 7404-5), or has a gross calorific value greater than 24 MJ/kg (determined in conformance with ISO 1928). Hard, black, organic rich sedimentary rock; contains less than 91 percent fixed carbon on a dry, mineral-matter-free basis, and greater than 13-14 percent volatiles (dry, ash free). Formed from the compaction or induration of variously altered plant remains similar to those of peaty deposits. Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.BlueschistMetamorphicRock
member.summary: Glaucophane lawsonite epidote metamorphic rock. A metamorphic rock of roughly basaltic composition, defined by the presence of glaucophane with lawsonite or epidote. Other minerals that may be present include jadeite, albite, chlorite, garnet, and muscovite (phengitic white mica). Typically fine-grained, dark colored. Category for rocks commonly referred to as blueschist. OneGeology, simplified for WITSML to blueschist metamorphic rock

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Boninite
member.summary: andesitic rock that contains more than 8 percent MgO. Typically consists of phenocrysts of protoenstatite, orthopyroxene, clinopyroxene, and olivine in a glassy base full of crystallites, and exhibits textures characterisitc of rapid crystal growth. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Breccia
member.summary: Coarse-grained material composed of angular broken rock fragments; the fragments typically have sharp edges and unworn corners. The fragments may be held together by a mineral cement or in a fine-grained matrix, and consolidated or nonconsolidated. Clasts may be of any composition or origin. In sedimentary environments, breccia is used for material that consists entirely of angular fragments, mostly derived from a single source rock body, as in a rock avalanche deposit, and matrix is interpreted to be the product of comminution of clasts during transport. Diamictite or diamicton is used when the material reflects mixing of rock from a variety of sources, some sub angular or subrounded clasts may be present, and matrix is pre-existing fine grained material that is not a direct product of the brecciation/deposition process. Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Calcarenite
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "impure limestone".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Calcilutite
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "impure limestone".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Calcisiltite
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "impure limestone".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.CarbonateOoze
member.summary: Ooze that consists of more than 50 percent carbonate skeletal remains. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Carbonatite
member.summary: Igneous rock composed of more than 50 percent modal carbonate minerals. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Chalk
member.summary: A generally soft, white, very fine-grained, extremely pure, porous limestone. It forms under marine conditions from the gradual accumulation of skeletal elements from minute planktonic green algae (cocoliths), associated with varying proportions of larger microscopic fragments of bivalves, foraminifera and ostracods. It is common to find flint and chert nodules embedded in chalk. C.S. Harris, 2009

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Chert
member.summary: Sedimentary rock that consists of at least 50 percent silicate mineral material, deposited directly by chemical or biological processes at the depositional surface, or in particles formed by chemical or biological processes within the basin of deposition. SLTTs 2004.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Clay
member.summary: Mud that consists of greater than 50 percent particles with grain size less than 0.004 mm.based on SLTTs 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005; particle size from Wentworth grade scale.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Claystone
member.summary: Mudstone that contains no detectable silt, inferred to consist virtually entirely of clay-size particles. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Coal
member.summary: A consolidated organic sedimentary material having less than 75 percent moisture. This category includes low, medium, and high rank coals according to International Classification of In-Seam Coal (United Nations, 1998), thus including lignite. Sapropelic coal is not distinguished in this category from humic coals. Formed from the compaction or induration of variously altered plant remains similar to those of peaty deposits. Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Conglomerate
member.summary: Clastic sedimentary rock composed of at least 30 percent rounded to subangular fragments larger than 2 millimeter in diameter; typically contains finer grained material in interstices between larger fragments. If more than 15 percent of the fine grained matrix is of indeterminant clastic or diagenetic origin and the fabric is matrix supported, may also be categorized as wackestone. If rock has unsorted or poorly sorted texture with a wide range of particle sizes, may also be categorized as diamictite. Neuendorf et al. 2005; SLTTs 2004.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Dacite
member.summary: Fine grained or porphyritic crystalline rock that contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 20 and 60 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction, and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.65. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 4 and 5 or chemically in TAS Field O3. Typcially composed of quartz and sodic plagioclase with minor amounts of biotite and/or hornblende and/or pyroxene; fine-grained equivalent of granodiorite and tonalite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Diabase
member.summary: Igneous rock of grain size intermediate between basalt and gabbro composed of plagioclase feldspar, pyroxene and opaque minerals. Synonym: dolerite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Diamictite
member.summary: Unsorted or poorly sorted, clastic sedimentary rock with a wide range of particle sizes including a muddy matrix. Biogenic materials that have such texture are excluded. Distinguished from conglomerate, sandstone, mudstone based on polymodality and lack of structures related to transport and deposition of sediment by moving air or water. If more than 10 percent of the fine grained matrix is of indeterminant clastic or diagenetic origin and the fabric is matrix supported, may also be categorized as wacke. Fairbridge and Bourgeois 1978.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Diorite
member.summary: Plutonic igneous rock consisting of plagioclase feldspar, commonly with hornblende and biotite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Dioritoid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock with M less than 90, consisting of intermediate plagioclase, commonly with hornblende and often with biotite or augite. Plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is greater that 0.65, and anorthite content of plagioclase is less than 50 percent. Less than 10 percent feldspathoid mineral and less than 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 (and their subdivisions). LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.DoleriticRock
member.summary: Dark colored gabbroic (basaltic) or dioritic (andesitic) rock intermediate in grain size between basalt and gabbro and composed of plagioclase, pyroxene and opaque minerals; often with ophitic texture. Typically occurs as hypabyssal intrusions. Includes dolerite, microdiorite, diabase and microgabbro. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Dolomite
member.summary: Pure carbonate sedimentary rock with a ratio of magnesium carbonate to calcite (plus aragonite) greater than 1 to 1. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.DolomiteCalcareous
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "impure dolomite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Eclogite
member.summary: Metamorphic rock composed of 75 percent or more (by volume) omphacite and garnet, both of which are present as major constituents, the amount of neither of them being higher than 75 percent (by volume); the presence of plagioclase precludes classification as an eclogite. IUGS SCMR 2007

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.ExoticAlkalineRock
member.summary: Kimberlite, lamproite, or lamprophyre. Generally are potassic, mafic or ultramafic rocks. Olivine (commonly serpentinized in kimberlite), and phlogopite are significant constituents. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.ExtrusiveRockVolcanic
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "fragmental igneous rock".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Feldspar
member.summary: The family of aluminium silicates of sodium, potassium, calcium and other metals which comprise over 60% of the earth's crust, are the most abundant mineral group, and occur in all types of rocks.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.FeldspathicArenite
member.summary: Clastic sandstone that contains less than 10 percent matrix. Matrix is mud-size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products) of detrital or diagenetic nature. Sandstones that contain less than 90 percent quartz.Dott, R. H, (1964). Wacke, Graywacke and matrix-what approach to immature sandstone classification: Journal of Sedimentary Petrology, v-34, p. 625-632.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.FineGrainedIgneousRock
member.summary: Undifferentaited Igneous rock in which the framework of the rock consists of crystals that are too small to determine mineralogy with the unaided eye; framework may include up to 50 percent glass. A significant percentage of the rock by volume may be phenocrysts. Includes rocks that are generally called volcanic rocks. Gillespie and Styles 1999; LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.FoidDioritoid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock in which M is less than 90, the plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is greater than 0.5, feldspathoid minerals form 10-60 percent of the QAPF fraction, plagioclase has anorthite content less than 50 percent. These rocks typically contain large amounts of mafic minerals. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 13 and 14. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.FoidGabbroid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock in which M is less than 90, the plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is greater than 0.5, feldspathoids form 10-60 percent of the QAPF fraction, and plagioclase has anorthite content greater than 50 percent. These rocks typically contain large amounts of mafic minerals. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 13 and 14. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.FoidSyenitoid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock with M less than 90, contains between 10 and 60 percent feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction, and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio less than 0.5. Includes QAPF fields 11 and 12. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Foidite
member.summary: Foiditoid that contains greater than 90 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Foiditoid
member.summary: Fine grained crystalline rock containing less than 90 percent mafic minerals and more than 60 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 15 or chemically in TAS field F. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Foidolite
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline rock containing more than 60 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 15. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.FoliatedMetamorphicRock
member.summary: Metamorphic rock in which 10 percent or more of the contained mineral grains are elements in a planar or linear fabric. Cataclastic or glassy character precludes classification with this concept. Based on NADM SLTT metamorphic.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.FragmentalIgneousRock
member.summary: Igneous rock in which greater than 75 percent of the rock consists of fragments produced as a result of igneous rock-forming process. Includes pyroclastic rocks, autobreccia associated with lava flows and intrusive breccias. Excludes deposits reworked by epiclastic processes (see Tuffite).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Gabbro
member.summary: Gabbroic rock that contains between 0 and 5 percent quartz and no feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF Field 10 as gabbro. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.GabbroicRock
member.summary: Gabbroid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.9 in the QAPF fraction. Includes QAPF fields 10*, 10, and 10'. This category includes the various categories defined in LeMaitre et al. (2002) based on the mafic mineralogy, but apparently not subdivided based on the quartz/feldspathoid content. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Gabbroid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock that contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, and up to 20 percent quartz or up to 10 percent feldspathoid in the QAPF fraction. The ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is greater than 0.65, and anorthite content of the plagioclase is greater than 50 percent. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 and their subdivisions. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Glauconite
member.summary: A mineral composed of ferrous potassium silicates related to mica which commonly imparts a green color to its sedimentary host rock.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Gneiss
member.summary: Foliated metamorphic rock with bands or lenticles rich in granular minerals alternating with bands or lenticles rich in minerals with a flaky or elongate prismatic habit. Mylonitic foliation or well developed, continuous schistosity (greater than 50 percent of the rock consists of grains participate in a planar or linear fabric) precludes classification with this concept. Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Granite
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline rock consisting of quartz, alkali feldspar and plagioclase (typically sodic) in variable amounts, usually with biotite and/or hornblende. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF Field 3. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Granodiorite
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline rock consisting essentially of quartz, sodic plagioclase and lesser amounts of alkali feldspar with minor hornblende and biotite. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 4. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Granofels
member.summary: Metamorphic rock with granoblastic fabric and very little or no foliation (less than 10 percent of the mineral grains in the rock are elements in a planar or linear fabric). Grainsize not specified. SLTTm 2004.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Granulite
member.summary: Metamorphic rock of high metamorphic grade in which Fe-Mg silicate minerals are dominantly hydroxl-free; feldspar must be present, and muscovite is absent; rock contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, less than 75 percent calcite and/or dolomite, less than 75 percent quartz, less than 50 percent iron-bearing minerals (hematite, magnetite, limonite-group, siderite, iron-sulfides), and less than 50 percent calc-silicate minerals. Fettes and Desmons (2007). See also Wimmenauer (1985), Winkler (1979) (D.R. Bowes (1989), The Encyclopedia of Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology; Van Nostrand Reinhold ISBN: 0-442-20623-2

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Gravel
member.summary: Clastic sediment containing greater than 30 percent gravel-size particles (greater than 2.0 millimeter diameter). Gravel in which more than half of the particles are of epiclastic origin.definition of gravel from SLTTs 2004; particle sizes defined from Krumbein phi scale (W C Krumbein & L L Sloss, Stratigraphy and Sedimentation, 2nd edition, Freeman, San Francisco, 1963; Krumbein and Pettijohn, 1938, Manual of Sedimentary Petrography: New York, Appleton Century Co., Inc.).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Greenstone
member.summary: Chlorite actinolite epidote metamorphic rocks. Metamorphic rock characterized by 50 percent or more of combined chlorite, actinolite and epidote. Category for rocks generally named greenschist or greenstone. OneGeology, simplified for WITSML to Greenstone.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Greenstones
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "greenstone".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Greywacke
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "wacke".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Gumbo
member.summary: A term used in the U.S. for clay soils that become sticky, impervious, and plastic when wet.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Gypsum
member.summary: Evaporite composed of at least 50 percent gypsum . OneGeology / WITSML

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Halite
member.summary: Evaporite composed of at least 90 percent halite.(NaCl). Use Rock Salt if unclear on chemical composition. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Hornfels
member.summary: Granofels formed by contact metamorphism, composed of a mosaic of equidimensional grains in a characteristically granoblastic or decussate matrix; porphyroblasts or relict phenocrysts may be present. Typically fine grained.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Igneous
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "igneous rock".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.IgneousRock
member.summary: Undefined rock formed as a result of igneous processes, for example intrusion and cooling of magma in the crust, or volcanic eruption. Neuendorf et al 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.ImpactGeneratedMaterial
member.summary: Material that contains features indicative of shock metamorphism, such as microscopic planar deformation features within grains or shatter cones, interpreted to be the result of extraterrestrial bolide impact. Includes breccias and melt rocks. Stffler and Grieve 2007; Jackson 1997.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.ImpureDolomite
member.summary: Impure carbonate sedimentary rock with a ratio of magnesium carbonate to calcite (plus aragonite) greater than 1 to 1. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.ImpureLimestone
member.summary: Impure carbonate sedimentary rock with a calcite (plus aragonite) to dolomite ratio greater than 1 to 1. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.IntrusiveRockPlutonic
member.summary: Igneous rock formed by cooling and solidification of magma within the earth's crust.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.IronRichSedimentaryRock
member.summary: Sedimentary rock that consists of at least 50 percent iron-bearing minerals (hematite, magnetite, limonite-group, siderite, iron-sulfides), as determined by hand-lens or petrographic analysis. Corresponds to a rock typically containing 15 percent iron by weight. Hallsworth and Knox 1999; SLTTs 2004.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.KalsiliticAndMeliliticRocks
member.summary: Igneous rock containing greater than 10 percent melilite or kalsilite. Typically undersaturated, ultrapotassic (kalsilitic rocks) or calcium-rich (melilitic rocks) mafic or ultramafic rocks. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.KomatiiticRock
member.summary: Ultramafic, magnesium-rich volcanic rock, typically with spinifex texture of intergrown skeletal and bladed olivine and pyroxene crystals set in abundant glass. Includes komatiite and meimechite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.LatiticRock
member.summary: Trachytoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.35 and 0.65. QAPF fields 8, 8' and 8*. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Lignite
member.summary: Coal that has a gross calorific value less than 24 MJ/kg (determined in conformance with ISO 1928), and vitrinite mean random reflectance less than 0.6 percent (determined in conformance with ISO 7404-5). Gross calorific value is recalculated to a moist, ash free basis using bed moisture (determined according to ISO 1015 or ISO 5068). Includes all low-rank coals, including sub-bitiminous coal. A consolidated, dull, soft brown to black coal having many readily discernible plant fragments set in a finer grained organic matrix. Tends to crack and fall apart on drying. Operationally sub-bituminous and bitiminous coal are qualitatively distinguished based on brown streak for sub-bitiminous coal and black streak for bituminous coal. Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.LimeBoundstone
member.summary: Biogenic textural class. The origianl components were bound and encrusted together by the action of plants and animals in the position of growth. That is, Reef limestones. Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.LimeFramestone
member.summary: Biogenic textural class. Carbonate reef rock consisting of a rigid framework of colonies, shells or skeletons, with internal cavities filled with fine sediment; usually created through the activities of colonial organisms. Source () Hallsworth & Knox 1999; SLTTs 2004, Table 15-3-1

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.LimeGrainstone
member.summary: Depositional textural cassification. Grain supported carbonate with little ( less than 25 percent) carbonate matrix. Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.LimeMudstone
member.summary: Depositional textural cassification. Original components not bound together during deposition. Contains mud (clay and fine silt-size carbonate). Mud-supported (particles greater than 20 mm). Less than 10 percent Grains. Mudstone that contains between 10 and 50 percent carbonate minerals in the mud size fraction. Carbonate origin is not specified. The operational test typically used to identify this category is if the rock fizzes when hydrochloric acid is applied. The '10 percent carbonate' criteria is a fuzzy boundary.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.LimePackstone
member.summary: Grain supported carbonate. Original components not bound together during deposition. Contains mud (clay and fine silt-size carbonate). Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.LimeWackestone
member.summary: Depositional textural cassification. Original components not bound together during deposition. Matrix supported. Contains less than 75 percent mud grade (less than 32 micrometer) calcite. (clay and fine silt-size carbonate). Mud-supported (particles greater than 20 mm). Greater than 10 percent Grains. Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Limestone
member.summary: Pure carbonate sedimentary rock with a calcite (plus aragonite) to dolomite ratio greater than 1 to 1. Includes limestone and dolomitic limestone. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.LimestoneArgillaceous
member.summary: A limestone homogeneously mixed with 10-50% clay minerals.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.LimestoneDolomitic
member.summary: A limestone containing 10-50% dolomite and 50-90% calcite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.LimestoneSandy
member.summary: A limestone homogeneously mixed with 10-50% quartz grains.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Marble
member.summary: Metamorphic rock consisting of greater than 75 percent fine- to coarse-grained recrystallized calcite and/or dolomite; usually with a granoblastic, saccharoidal texture. IUGS SCMR 2007

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Marl
member.summary: A consolidated or semi-consolidated mixture of clay and generally fine grained carbonate material.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.MetamorphicRock
member.summary: Undefined rock formed by solid-state mineralogical, chemical and/or structural changes to a pre-existing rock, in response to marked changes in temperature, pressure, shearing stress and chemical environment. Not further defined. Jackson 1997.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.MetamorphicRocks
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "metamorphic rock".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.MicaSchist
member.summary: A schist that consists of more than 50 percent mica minerals, typically muscovite or biotite. Special type included to distinguish this common variety of schist. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Migmatite
member.summary: Silicate metamorphic rock that is pervasively heterogeneous on a decimeter to meter scale that typically consists of darker and lighter parts; the darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks whereas the lighter parts are of igneous-looking appearance. Fette and Desmons (2007)

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Monzogabbro
member.summary: Monzogabbroic rock that contains between 0 an 5 percent quartz and no feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 9. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Mud
member.summary: Clastic sediment consisting of less than 30 percent gravel-size (2 mm) particles and with a mud-size to sand-size particle ratio greater than 1. More than half of the particles are of epiclastic origin. Definition of mud from SLTTs 2004 muddy sediment; particle sizes defined from Krumbein phi scale (W C Krumbein & L L Sloss, Stratigraphy and Sedimentation, 2nd edition, Freeman, San Francisco, 1963; Krumbein and Pettijohn, 1938, Manual of Sedimentary Petrography: New York, Appleton Century Co., Inc.).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Mudstone
member.summary: Clastic sedimentary rock consisting of less than 30 percent gravel-size (2 mm) particles and with a mud to sand ratio greater than 1. The definition includes Claystone, Siltstone and Shale. Pettijohn et al. 1987 referenced in Hallsworth & Knox 1999; extrapolated from Folk, 1954, Figure 1a.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.MyloniticRock
member.summary: Metamorphic rock characterised by a foliation resulting from tectonic grain size reduction, in which more than 10 percent of the rock volume has undergone grain size reduction. Includes protomylonite, mylonite, ultramylonite, and blastomylonite. Marshak & Mitra 1988.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.NoDescription
member.summary: No description is provided.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.NoSample
member.summary: A sample would be expected, given the drilling situation, but nothing was seen at the shakers, implying either solution in the mud system of a salt, or lack of returns. WITSML.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Ooze
member.summary: Biogenic sediment consisting of less than 1 percent gravel-size (greater than or equal to 2 mm) particles, with a sand to mud ratio less than 1 to 9, and less than 50 percent carbonate minerals. Based on Bates and Jackson 1987 & Hallsworth & Knox 1999.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Ophiolite
member.summary: Basic and ultra-basic igneous rocks and their metamorposed, often hydrated, derivatives, believed to represent former oceanic crust.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.OrganicBearingMudstone
member.summary: Mudstone that contains a significant amount of organic carbon, typically kerogen. Commonly finely laminated, brown or black in color. Neuendorf et al. 2005;

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Peat
member.summary: Unconsolidated organic-rich sediment composed of at least 50 percent semi-carbonised plant remains; individual remains commonly seen with unaided eye; yellowish brown to brownish black; generally fibrous texture; can be plastic or friable. In its natural state it can be readily cut and has a very high moisture content, generally greater than 90 percent. Liptinite to Inertinite ratio is less than one (Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.). Hallsworth & Knox 1999.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Pegmatite
member.summary: Exceptionally coarse grained crystalline rock with interlocking crystals; most grains are 1 centimeter or more diameter; composition is generally that of granite, but the term may refer to the coarse grained facies of any type of igneous rock; usually found as irregular dikes, lenses, or veins associated with plutons or batholiths. Neuendorf et al 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Peridotite
member.summary: Ultramafic rock consisting of more than 40 percent (by volume) olivine with pyroxene and/or amphibole and little or no feldspar. Commonly altered to serpentinite. Includes rocks defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification as dunite, harzburgite, lherzolite, wehrlite, olivinite, pyroxene peridotite, pyroxene hornblende peridotite or hornblende peridotite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.PhaneriticIgneousRock
member.summary: Igneous rock in which the framework of the rock consists of individual crystals that can be discerned with the unaided eye. Bounding grain size is on the order of 32 to 100 microns. Igneous rocks with 'exotic' composition are excluded from this concept. Neuendorf et al 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Phonolite
member.summary: Phonolitoid in which the plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is less than 0.1. Rock consists of alkali feldspar, feldspathoid minerals, and mafic minerals. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Phonolitoid
member.summary: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 10 and 60 percent feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio less than 0.5. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 11 and 12, and TAS field Ph. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Phosphate
member.summary: Any mineral compound containing the ((PO4)3) radical.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.PhosphateRock
member.summary: Any rock containing phosphate minerals such as apatite of sufficient purity and abundance to be an economic resource.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Phyllite
member.summary: Rock with a well developed, continuous schistosity, an average grain size between 0.1 and 0.5 millimeters, and a silvery sheen on cleavage surfaces. Individual phyllosilicate grains are barely visible with the unaided eye. IUGS SCMR 2007.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Porphyry
member.summary: Igneous rock that contains conspicuous phenocrysts in a finer grained groundmass; groundmass itself may be phaneritic or fine-grained. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.PotassiumAndMagnesiumSalts
member.summary: Evaporite composed with significant (greater than 50 percent) magnesium salts, such as Carnallite /Kainite/Polyhalite/Kieserite/Bischofite/Tachydrite. WITSML.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.PyroclasticBreccia
member.summary: Pyroclastic rock in which greater than 25 percent of particles are greater than 64 millimeter in largest dimension. Includes agglomerate, pyroclastic breccia of Gillespie and Styles (1999). Schmid 1981; LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.PyroclasticRock
member.summary: Fragmental igneous rock that consists of greater than 75 percent fragments produced as a direct result of eruption or extrusion of magma from within the earth onto its surface. Includes autobreccia associated with lava flows and excludes deposits reworked by epiclastic processes. Based on LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Pyroxenite
member.summary: Ultramafic phaneritic igneous rock composed almost entirely of one or more pyroxenes and occasionally biotite, hornblende and olivine. Includes rocks defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification as olivine pyroxenite, olivine-hornblende pyroxenite, pyroxenite, orthopyroxenite, clinopyroxenite and websterite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.QuartzArenite
member.summary: Clastic sandstone that contains less than 10 percent matrix. Matrix is mud-size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products) of detrital or diagenetic nature. Sandstones that contain more than 90 percent of siliceous grains. Grains can include quartz or chert rock fragments. Dott, R. H, (1964). Wacke, Graywacke and matrix-what approach to immature sandstone classification: Journal of Sedimentary Petrology, v-34, p. 625-632.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Quartzite
member.summary: Metamorphic rock consisting of greater than or equal to 75 percent quartz; typically granoblastic texture. Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Rhyolite
member.summary: rhyolitoid in which the ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is between 0.1 and 0.65. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.RockSalt
member.summary: Evaporite composed of at least 50 percent halite. Superset of Halite, Silvite and Potassium and magnesium salts. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Salt
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "rock salt".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Sand
member.summary: Clastic sediment in which less than 30 percent of particles are gravel (greater than 2 millimeter in diameter) and the sand to mud ratio is at least 1. More than half of the particles are of epiclastic origin.definition of sand from SLTTs 2004 sandy sediment; particle sizes defined from Krumbein phi scale (W C Krumbein & L L Sloss, Stratigraphy and Sedimentation, 2nd edition, Freeman, San Francisco, 1963; Krumbein and Pettijohn, 1938, Manual of Sedimentary Petrography: New York, Appleton Century Co., Inc.).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Sandstone
member.summary: Clastic sedimentary rock in which less than 30 percent of particles are greater than 2 millimeter in diameter (gravel) and the sand to mud ratio is at least 1. SLTTs 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005; particle size from Wentworth grade scale.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Sapropel
member.summary: Jelly like organic rich sediment composed of plant remains, usually algal. Liptinite to Inertinite ratio is greater than one (Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.). Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Schist
member.summary: Foliated phaneritic metamorphic rock with well developed, continuous schistosity, meaning that greater than 50 percent of the rock by volume is mineral grains with a thin tabular, lamellar, or acicular prismatic crystallographic habit that are oriented in a continuous planar or linear fabric. SLTTm 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Serpentine
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "serpentinite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Serpentinite
member.summary: Rock consisting of more than 75 percent serpentine-group minerals, eg. antigorite, chrysotile or lizardite; accessory chlorite, talc and magnetite may be present; derived from hydration of ferromagnesian silicate minerals such as olivine and pyroxene. Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Shale
member.summary: Laminated mudstone that will part or break along thin, closely spaced layers parallel to stratification. NADM SLTT sedimentary, 2004. WITSML note: Since Hallsworth and Knox did not recognise the term Shale, some operators do not use this in descriptions, but do plot it graphically.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.SiliceousOoze
member.summary: Ooze that consists of more than 50 percent siliceous skeletal remains. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Silt
member.summary: Mud that consists of greater than 50 percent silt-size grains. Based on SLTTs 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005; particle size from Wentworth grade scale.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Siltstone
member.summary: Mudstone that contains detectable silt. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Skarn
member.summary: Metasomatic rock consisting mainly of Ca-, Mg-, Fe-, or Mn-silicate minerals, which are free from or poor in water. Typically formed at the contact between a silicate rock or magma and a carbonate rock.Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p195.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Slate
member.summary: Compact, fine grained rock with an average grain size less than 0.032 millimeter and a well developed schistosity (slaty cleavage), and hence can be split into slabs or thin plates. NADM metamorphic rock vocabulary SLTTm1.0; Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Spilite
member.summary: Altered basic to intermediate composition fine-grained igneous rock in which the feldspar is partially or completely composed of of albite, typically accompanied by chlorite, calcite, quartz, epidote, prehnite, and low-temperature hydrous crystallization products. Preservation of eruptive volcanic features is typical. Fettes and Desmon, 2007; Best, M.G., 1982, Igneous and metamorphic petrology: New York, W.H. Freeman and Company, p. 398; Neuendorf et al. 2005, p. 619.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Syenite
member.summary: Plutonic igneous rock composed essentially of alkali feldspar, with lesser sodic plagioclase, biotite and hornblende, and minor quartz.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Syenitoid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock with M less than 90, consisting mainly of alkali feldspar and plagioclase; minor quartz or nepheline may be present, along with pyroxene, amphibole or biotite. Ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is less than 0.65, quartz forms less than 20 percent of QAPF fraction, and feldspathoid minerals form less than 10 percent of QAPF fraction. Includes rocks classified in QAPF fields 6, 7 and 8 and their subdivisions. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Sylvite
member.summary: Evaporite composed of at least 50 percent Sylvite (KCL). OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Tephrite
member.summary: Tephritoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.9, and contains less than 10 percent normative (CIPW) olivine. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Tephritoid
member.summary: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 10 and 60 percent feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.5. Includes rocks classified in QAPF field 13 and 14 or chemically in TAS field U1 as basanite or tephrite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.TholeiiticBasalt
member.summary: Tholeiitic basalt is defined here to contain 2 pyroxene phases and interstitial quartz or tridymite or cristobalite in the groundmass. Pyroxene (augite and orthopyroxene or pigeonite) and calcium-rich plagioclase are common phenocryst minerals. Olivine may also be a phenocryst, and when present, may have rims of pigeonite. Only in tholeiitic basalt is olivine in reaction relationship with melt. Interstitial siliceous residue may be present, and is often glassy. Tholeiitic basalt is relatively poor in sodium. This category includes most basalts of the ocean floor, most large oceanic islands, and continental flood basalts such as the Columbia River Plateau.Carmichael, I.S. Turner, F.J., Verhoogen, John, 1974, Igneous petrology: New York, McGraw HIll Book Co., p.42-43.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.TilliteDiamictite
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "diamictite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Tonalite
member.summary: Granitoid consisting of quartz and intermediate plagioclase, usually with biotite and amphibole. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 5; ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is greater than 0.9. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Trachyte
member.summary: A group of fine-grained often porphyritic volcanic rocks containing alkali feldspar and minor mafic minerals.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.TrachyticRock
member.summary: Trachytoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.1 and 0.35. QAPF fields 7, 7', and 7*. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Trachytoid
member.summary: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, less than 10 percent feldspathoid mineral and less than 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio less than 0.65. Mafic minerals typically include amphibole or mica; typically porphyritic. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 6, 7 and 8 (with subdivisions) or chemically in TAS Field T as trachyte or latite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Travertine
member.summary: Biotically or abiotically precipitated calcium carbonate, from spring-fed, heated, or ambient-temperature water. May be white and spongy, various shades of orange, tan or gray, and ranges to dense, banded or laminated rock. Macrophytes, bryophytes, algae, cyanobacteria and other organisms often colonize the surface of travertine and may be preserved, to produce the porous varieties. Neuendorf et al. 2005; Chafetz, H.S., and Folk, R.L., 1984, Travertine: Depositional morphology an dthe bacterially constructed constituents: J. Sed. Petrology, v. 126, p.57-74.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Tuff
member.summary: Ash tuff, lapillistone, and lapilli tuff. Pyroclastic rock in which less than 25 percent of rock by volume are more than 64 millimeter in longest diameter. Includes tuff, lapilli tuff, and lapillistone. Schmid 1981; LeMaitre et al. 2002. Modified by WITSML to just use the term Tuff.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Tuffite
member.summary: Rock consists of more than 50 percent particles of indeterminate pyroclastic or epiclastic origin and less than 75 percent particles of clearly pyroclastic origin. Commonly the rock is laminated or exhibits size grading. (based on LeMaitre et al. 2002; Murawski and Meyer 1998).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Ultrabasic
member.summary: A class of igneous rocks composed mostly of mafic minerals such as pyroxenes along with calcic feldspar, with no free silica and a total silica content less than about 45%.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Undifferentiated
member.summary: The lithology is not differentiated. This is typically used to fill out a lithology description to 100 percent.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Wacke
member.summary: Clastic sandstone with more than 10 percent matrix of indeterminate detrital or diagenetic nature. Matrix is mud size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products). Pettijohn, Potter, Siever, 1972, Sand and Sandstone: New York, Springer Verlag, 681 p.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.LithologyType.Unknown
member.summary: The value is not known. This value should not be used in normal situations. All reasonable attempts should be made to determine the appropriate value. Use of this value may result in rejection in some situations.

member.name: T:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType
member.summary: Lithology matrix/cement description.

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.#ctor
member.summary: Protected constructor, should always pass in "name"

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.GetList
member.summary: Retrieves the complete list of MatrixCementTypes

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.Ankerite
member.summary: A matrix cement dominantly composed of Ankerite. Ankerite is a calcium, iron, magnesium, manganese carbonate mineral of the group of rhombohedral carbonates with formula: Ca(Fe, Mg, Mn)(CO3)2. In composition it is closely related to dolomite, but differs from this in having magnesium replaced by varying amounts of iron(II) and manganese. ( AS a matrix cement it is seen in HP HT North Sea HPHT reservoirs such as Elgin and Franklin which have almost pure Ankerite cementation ),

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.Calcite
member.summary: A matrix cement dominantly composed of Calcite, the most stable polymorph of calcium carbonate (CaCO3), and readily identifiable at the wellsite due to its reaction with dilute hydrochloric acid. The most common matrix cement.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.Chlorite
member.summary: A matrix cement dominantly composed of Chlorite. It is a low grade metamorphic cement. The typical general formula is: (Mg,Fe)3(Si,Al)4O10(OH)2(Mg,Fe)3(OH)6.Seen in Algerian gas fields such as Teg.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.Dolomite
member.summary: A matrix cement dominantly composed of dolomite.Dolomite cement is composed predominantly of the mineral dolomite with a stoichiometric ratio of 50% or greater content of magnesium replacing calcium, often as a result of diagenesis .

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.Illite
member.summary: A matrix cement dominantly composed of Illite. Illite is a clay sized micaceous mineral. The chemical formula is given as (K,H3O)(Al,Mg,Fe)2(Si,Al)4O10[(OH)2,(H2O)],[2] but there is considerable ion substitution. Seen in Southern North Sea gas fields such as the "Village" fields area.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.Kaolinite
member.summary: A matrix cement dominantly composed of Kaolinite. A matrix cement with the chemical composition Al2Si2O5(OH)4. It is a soft, earthy, usually white mineral (dioctahedral phyllosilicate clay), produced by the chemical weathering of aluminium silicate minerals like feldspar.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.Quartz
member.summary: A matrix cement dominantly composed of Quartz, either from pressure solution grain to grain contact cementation or secondary quartz deposition. Fairly common.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.Siderite
member.summary: A matrix cement dominantly composed of Siderite. Siderite is composed of iron carbonate FeCO3. ( Sherwood sandstones, in the southern UK typical include Siderite cements)

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.Smectite
member.summary: A matrix cement dominantly composed of Smectite. Chemically Smectite is a hydrated sodium calcium aluminium magnesium silicate hydroxide (Na,Ca)0.33(Al,Mg)2(Si4O10)(OH)2nH2O. It will respond to changes in hydration, so may be altered in cuttings samples.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MatrixCementType.Unknown
member.summary: The value is not known. This value should not be used in normal situations. All reasonable attempts should be made to determine the appropriate value. Use of this value may result in rejection in some situations.

member.name: T:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass
member.summary: Defines classes of measures and their allowed units of measures. For a value whose underlying meaning conforms to one of these classes, any specified unit of measure must conform to the defined list. These are copied from the Energistics (POSC) Units Classes v2.2. The units of measure map to the POSC Units of Measure Dictionary v2.2.

member.summary: For measure classes, defines the base uom for conversion.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.MeasureUOMEnumValue.MeasureUom
member.summary: For measure classes, defines an allowed uom for the class.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.AbsorbedDose
member.summary: The amount of energy absorbed per mass.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.ActivityOfRadioactivity
member.summary: A measure of the radiation being emitted.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.ConcentrationOfB
member.summary: molar concentration of a substance

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.AmountOfSubstance
member.summary: molar amount of a substance

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.AnglePerTime
member.summary: The angular velocity. The rate of change of an angle.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.Attenuation
member.summary: A logarithmic, fractional change of some measure, generally power or amplitude, over a standard range. This is generally used for frequency attenuation over an octave.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.DataTransmissionSpeed
member.summary: used primarily for computer transmission rates.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.DeltaTemperature
member.summary: Delta temperature refers to temperature differences. For non-zero offset temperature scales, Fahrenheit and Celsius, the conversion formulas are different than for absolute temperatures.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.Dimensionless
member.summary: A dimensionless quantity is the ratio of two dimensional quantities. The quantity types are not apparent from the basic dimensionless class, but may be apparent in variations - such as area per area, volume per volume, or mass per mass.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.ElectrochemicalEquivalent
member.summary: An electrochemical equivalent differs from molarity in that the valence (oxidation reduction potential) of the element is also considered.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.FrequencyInterval
member.summary: An octave is a doubling of a frquency.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.GammaRayApiUnit
member.summary: This class is defined by the API, and is used for units of gamma ray log response.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.Ph
member.summary: The pH is a class that measures the hydrogen ion concentration (acidity).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.MeasureClass.Unknown
member.summary: The value is not known. This value should not be used in normal situations. All reasonable attempts should be made to determine the appropriate value. Use of this value may result in rejection in some situations.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagLocation.Box

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagLocation.Pin

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagLocation.Other

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagLocation.Unknown

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagNumberingScheme.SerialNumber
member.summary: Serial number contains a code which does not require any further knowledge of an encoding scheme to manipulate or process. The identifier is the only information in the 'tag'.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagNumberingScheme.Unknown

member.name: T:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagTechnology
member.summary: Defines the mechanisms for attaching an equipment tag to an item.

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagTechnology.#ctor
member.summary: Protected constructor, should always pass in "name"

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagTechnology.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagTechnology.GetList
member.summary: Retrieves the complete list of NameTagTechnologys

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagTechnology.Tagged
member.summary: Independent identification components attached or embedded to a larger component for purposes of identification of the larger component. Tags typically use electronic, radio or sound based technologies and that require a special non-optical device to read them. Radio Frequency Identification (RFID tags) are of this type, as are some magnetic and sound based identification technologies.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagTechnology.Labeled
member.summary: An optical label attached to a component. The label may be glued, riveted or attached by some other method and may contain a serial number, barcode or other optically recognized information. Note that a label may possibly have a combination of identifiers associated with it, such as a serial number, a barcode and an embedded RFID identifier. This would generate three nameTags for the one physical label, two of type 'label' for the barcode and serial number and one of type 'tagged' for the RFID identifier.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagTechnology.Intrinsic
member.summary: Identification technologies where the intrinsic properties of the component to be identified contain the identification information and no other unique code has been added. For example, some magnetic identification technologies use grooves machined into a component. Some components may also be identified, for example, by their individual sonic signature or optical profile.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagTechnology.Stamped
member.summary: An identification code physically stamped into the base material of the component to be identified. Note that if a serial number is stamped into a label attached to a component, 'labeled' should be used and not 'stamped'. Stamped identifiers can wear off but can not fall off.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagTechnology.Painted
member.summary: Painted or stenciled on the material.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagTechnology.Temporary
member.summary: Temporary identification codes marked with grease pencil, chalk, or such.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.NameTagTechnology.Unknown
member.summary: The value is not known. This value should not be used in normal situations. All reasonable attempts should be made to determine the appropriate value. Use of this value may result in rejection in some situations.

member.name: T:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind
member.summary: Defines the kind of objectGroup.

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind.#ctor
member.summary: Protected constructor, should always pass in "name"

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind.GetList
member.summary: Retrieves the complete list of ObjectGroupKinds

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind.Drilling
member.summary: Run of BHA tools from the time they go below the rotary table, to the time they come back up. The sequence element represents the BHA run number. The sequence1 element represents the BHA pass number within the run. The range elements represent the portion of the wellbore traversed by the BHA for that run.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind.Wireline
member.summary: Run of wirelilne tools from the time they go below the rotary table, to the time they come back up. The sequence element represents the wireline run (trip) number. The sequence1 element represents the pass number within the run. The range elements represent the portion of the wellbore traversed by the tool for that run.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind.PressureTest
member.summary: Run of pressure test tools from the time they go below the rotary table, to the time they come back up. The sequence element represents the pressure test run number. The sequence1 element represents the pass number within the run. The sequence2 element represents the test number within the pass. The range elements represent the portion of the wellbore traversed by the tool for that run. The reference elements represent the time and depth of the test.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind.FlowTest
member.summary: Run of flow test tools from the time they go below the rotary table, to the time they come back up. The sequence element represents the flow test run number. The sequence1 element represents the pass number within the run. The sequence2 element represents the test number within the pass. The range elements represent the portion of the wellbore traversed by the tool for that run. The reference elements represent the time and depth of the test.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind.HoleSection
member.summary: The group collects the data-objects which operate within a portion of the wellbore with the same hole size. The sequence element represents the ordered sequence of the hole size within the wellbore. A sequence number of one represents the shallowest section. The range elements represent the portion of the wellbore with the same hole size. The parameter with the name "holeSize" represents the numeric size of the hole and MUST be specified with a "length" unit of measure.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind.Coring
member.summary: The group collects the data-objects which relate to a cored interval. The sequence element represents the BHA run within which the core was taken. The range elements represent the portion of the wellbore from which the core was taken. The reference elements represent the time and depth of the core. The parameter with the name "coreLength" represents the numeric length of the core and MUST be specified with a "length" unit of measure.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind.DrillReport
member.summary: The group collects the data-objects which relate to a reporting period. The sequence element represents the Nth report. The range elements represent the portion of the wellbore which was drilled during the period. The reference date-time element represents the time of the end of the reporting period.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.ObjectGroupKind.Unknown
member.summary: The value is not known. This value should not be used in normal situations. All reasonable attempts should be made to determine the appropriate value. Use of this value may result in rejection in some situations.

member.name: T:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType
member.summary: These values represent the type of qualifier in lithology.

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.LithoTypeEnumValue.#ctor
member.summary: Protected constructor, should always pass in "name"

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.LithoTypeEnumValue.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.LithoTypeEnumValue.LithoType
member.summary: For lithology qualifiers, the type of qualifier: "noun", "adjective" or "both". For a qualifier which has a type of "both", the "noun" form must be specified as the qualifier value and an adjective form must be listed as a variant. The interpretation of whether a specified qualifier value represents a noun or a adjective is defined by its association with either an interval (adjective) or point (noun).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.LithoTypeEnumValue.VariantOf
member.summary: The name of the lithology qualifier for which this qualifier represents a variation of the same underlying concept. A variant will always represent either an adjective or a noun but not both.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.LithoTypeEnumValue.IsLithology
member.summary: True ("true" or "1") indicates that the qualifier is also in the LithologyType list. False ("false" or "0") indicates otherwise.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.EnumValue.LithoTypeEnumValue.IsMatrixCement
member.summary: True ("true" or "1") indicates that the qualifier is also in the MatrixCementType list. False ("false" or "0") indicates otherwise.

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.#ctor
member.summary: Protected constructor, should always pass in "name"

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.GetList
member.summary: Retrieves the complete list of QualifierTypes

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.AlkaliFeldsparRhyolite
member.summary: Rhyolitoid in which the ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is less than 0.1. QAPF field 2. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.AlkaliOlivineBasalt
member.summary: Alkali olivine basalt is silica-undersaturated, characterized by the absence of orthopyroxene, absence of quartz, presence of olivine, and typically contains some feldspathoid mineral, alkali feldspar or phlogopite in the groundmass. Feldspar phenocrysts typically are labradorite to andesine in composition. Augite is rich in titanium compared to augite in tholeiitic basalt. Alkali olivine basalt is relatively rich in sodium. Carmichael, I.S. Turner, F.J., Verhoogen, John, 1974, Igneous petrology: New York, McGraw HIll Book Co., p.42-43.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Amphibolite
member.summary: Metamorphic rock mainly consisting of green, brown or black amphibole and plagioclase (including albite), which combined form 75 percent or more of the rock, and both of which are present as major constituents. The amphibole constitutes 50 percent or more of the total mafic constituents and is present in an amount of 30 percent or more; other common minerals include quartz, clinopyroxene, garnet, epidote-group minerals, biotite, titanite and scapolite. Coutinho et al. 2007, IUGS SCMR chapter 8.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Amphibolitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "amphibolite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Andesite
member.summary: Fine-grained igneous rock with less than 20 percent quartz and less than 10 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction, in which the ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is greater 0.65. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 or chemically in TAS field O2 as andesite. Basalt and andesite, which share the same QAPF fields, are distinguished chemically based on silica content, with basalt defined to contain less than 52 weight percent silica. If chemical data are not available, the color index is used to distinguish the categories, with basalt defined to contain greater than 35 percent mafic minerals by volume or greater than 40 percent mafic minerals by weight. Typically consists of plagioclase (frequently zoned from labradorite to oligoclase), pyroxene, hornblende and/or biotite. Fine grained equivalent of dioritic rock. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Andesitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "andesite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Anhydrite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles the evaporite mineral anhydrite (CaSO4).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Anhydritic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "anhydrite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Ankerite
member.summary: A matrix cement dominantly composed of Ankerite. Ankerite is a calcium, iron, magnesium, manganese carbonate mineral of the group of rhombohedral carbonates with formula: Ca(Fe, Mg, Mn)(CO3)2. In composition it is closely related to dolomite, but differs from this in having magnesium replaced by varying amounts of iron(II) and manganese. ( AS a matrix cement it is seen in HP HT North Sea HPHT reservoirs such as Elgin and Franklin which have almost pure Ankerite cementation ),

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Ankeritic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "ankerite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.AnorthositicRock
member.summary: Leucocratic phaneritic crystalline igneous rock consisting essentially of plagioclase, often with small amounts of pyroxene. By definition, colour index M is less than 10, and plagiclase to total feldspar ratio is greater than 0.9. Less than 20 percent quartz and less than 10 percent feldspathoid in the QAPF fraction. QAPF field 10, 10*, and 10'. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Anthracite
member.summary: Coal that has vitrinite mean random reflectance greater than 2.0 percent (determined in conformance with ISO 7404-5).
