Less than 12-14 percent volatiles (dry, ash free), greater than 91 percent fixed carbon (dry, ash free basis). The highest rank coal; very hard, glossy, black, with semimetallic luster, semi conchoidal fracture. Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp; see also Neuendorf et al. 2005

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Anthracitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "anthracite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Aplite
member.summary: Light coloured crystalline rock, characterized by a fine grained allotriomorphic-granular (aplitic, saccharoidal or xenomorphic) texture; typically granitic composition, consisting of quartz, alkali feldspar and sodic plagioclase. Neuendorf et al 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Aplitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "aplite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Arenite
member.summary: Clastic sandstone that contains less than 10 percent matrix. Matrix is mud-size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products) of detrital or diagenetic nature. Pettijohn, Potter, Siever, 1972, Sand and Sandstone: New York, Springer Verlag, 681 p. WITSML note: In drill cuttings there is a tendancy for grains to break apart, and loose the matrix, so frequently Sandstone is used rather then Arenite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Arenitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "arenite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Argillaceous
member.summary: VARIANT. See "clay".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Arkose
member.summary: An indurated arenaceous deposit consisting chiefly of quartz and feldspar (greater than 25%).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Arkosic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "arkose".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Barite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains the mineral barite [baryte] (BaSO4).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Baritic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "barite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Basalt
member.summary: Fine-grained or porphyritic igneous rock with less than 20 percent quartz, and less than 10 percent feldspathoid minerals, in which the ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is greater 0.65. Typically composed of calcic plagioclase and clinopyroxene; phenocrysts typically include one or more of calcic plagioclase, clinopyroxene, orthopyroxene, and olivine. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 or chemically in TAS field B as basalt. Basalt and andesite are distinguished chemically based on silica content, with basalt defined to contain less than 52 weight percent silica. If chemical data are not available, the color index is used to distinguish the categories, with basalt defined to contain greater than 35 percent mafic minerals by volume or greater than 40 percent mafic minerals by weight. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Basaltic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "basalt".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Basanite
member.summary: Tephritoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.9, and contains more than 10 percent normative (CIPW) olivine. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Basanitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "basanite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Bauxite
member.summary: Highly aluminous material containing abundant aluminium hydroxides (gibbsite, less commonly boehmite, diaspore) and aluminium-substituted iron oxides or hydroxides and generally minor or negligible kaolin minerals; may contain up to 20 percent quartz. Commonly has a pisolitic or nodular texture, and may be cemented. Eggleton 2001.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Bauxitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "bauxite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Belemnites
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains belemnite (Carboniferous - Eocene) fossils or fragments thereof.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Belemnitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "belemnites".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Bioturbated
member.summary: VARIANT. See "bioturbation".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Bioturbation
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology has been disturbed by the (burrowing) activities of organisms before consolidation of the sediment.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Bitumen
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling bitumen (asphalt), pitch or tar.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Bituminous
member.summary: VARIANT. See "bitumen".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.BituminousCoal
member.summary: Coal that has vitrinite mean random reflectance greater than 0.6 percent and less than 2.0 percent (determined in conformance with ISO 7404-5), or has a gross calorific value greater than 24 MJ/kg (determined in conformance with ISO 1928). Hard, black, organic rich sedimentary rock; contains less than 91 percent fixed carbon on a dry, mineral-matter-free basis, and greater than 13-14 percent volatiles (dry, ash free). Formed from the compaction or induration of variously altered plant remains similar to those of peaty deposits. Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.BlueschistMetamorphicRock
member.summary: Glaucophane lawsonite epidote metamorphic rock. A metamorphic rock of roughly basaltic composition, defined by the presence of glaucophane with lawsonite or epidote. Other minerals that may be present include jadeite, albite, chlorite, garnet, and muscovite (phengitic white mica). Typically fine-grained, dark colored. Category for rocks commonly referred to as blueschist. OneGeology, simplified for WITSML to blueschist metamorphic rock

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Boninite
member.summary: andesitic rock that contains more than 8 percent MgO. Typically consists of phenocrysts of protoenstatite, orthopyroxene, clinopyroxene, and olivine in a glassy base full of crystallites, and exhibits textures characterisitc of rapid crystal growth. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Breccia
member.summary: Coarse-grained material composed of angular broken rock fragments; the fragments typically have sharp edges and unworn corners. The fragments may be held together by a mineral cement or in a fine-grained matrix, and consolidated or nonconsolidated. Clasts may be of any composition or origin. In sedimentary environments, breccia is used for material that consists entirely of angular fragments, mostly derived from a single source rock body, as in a rock avalanche deposit, and matrix is interpreted to be the product of comminution of clasts during transport. Diamictite or diamicton is used when the material reflects mixing of rock from a variety of sources, some sub angular or subrounded clasts may be present, and matrix is pre-existing fine grained material that is not a direct product of the brecciation/deposition process. Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Brecciated
member.summary: VARIANT. See "breccia".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Bryozoan
member.summary: VARIANT. See "bryozoans".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Bryozoans
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or is characteristic of bryozoan (Ordovician - Recent) fossils or fragments thereof.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Burrowed
member.summary: VARIANT. See "burrows".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Burrows
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology has been disturbed by burrowing organisms before consolidation of the sediment.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Calcareous
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or characteristic of calcium carbonate (CaCO3).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Calcite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling the crystalline form of calcium carbonate (CaCO3).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.CalciteConcr
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "calcite concretion".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.CalciteConcretion
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains rounded nodules of crystalline calcium carbonate.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Calcitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "calcite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Carbonaceous
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or yielding carbon.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.CarbonateOoze
member.summary: Ooze that consists of more than 50 percent carbonate skeletal remains. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Carbonatite
member.summary: Igneous rock composed of more than 50 percent modal carbonate minerals. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Carbonatitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "carbonatite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Chalk
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling a soft compact form of calcium carbonate (CaCO3).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Chalky
member.summary: VARIANT. See "chalk".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Chamosite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles chamosite, a generally greenish-gray or black silicate mineral of iron and aluminium.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Chamositic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "chamosite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Chert
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles the microcrystalline or cryptocrystalline form of quartz (SiO2).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Cherty
member.summary: VARIANT. See "chert".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Chlorite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles chlorite, a generally green or black flaky phyllosilicate mineral.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Chloritic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "chlorite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Clay
member.summary: Mud that consists of greater than 50 percent particles with grain size less than 0.004 mm.based on SLTTs 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005; particle size from Wentworth grade scale.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Claystone
member.summary: Mudstone that contains no detectable silt, inferred to consist virtually entirely of clay-size particles. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Coal
member.summary: A consolidated organic sedimentary material having less than 75 percent moisture. This category includes low, medium, and high rank coals according to International Classification of In-Seam Coal (United Nations, 1998), thus including lignite. Sapropelic coal is not distinguished in this category from humic coals. Formed from the compaction or induration of variously altered plant remains similar to those of peaty deposits. Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Concretionary
member.summary: VARIANT. See "concretions".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Concretions
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains rounded masses of mineral material.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Conglomerate
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains rounded rock fragments of greater than 20mm in size.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Conglomeratic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "conglomerate".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Coral
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "coral fragments".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.CoralFragments
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles corals (late Pre-Cambrian - Recent) and/or coral fragments.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Coralline
member.summary: VARIANT. See "coral fragments".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Crinoidal
member.summary: VARIANT. See "crinoids".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Crinoids
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles crinoids (Mid Cambrian - Recent) and/or crinoid fragments.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Dacite
member.summary: Fine grained or porphyritic crystalline rock that contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 20 and 60 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction, and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.65. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 4 and 5 or chemically in TAS Field O3. Typcially composed of quartz and sodic plagioclase with minor amounts of biotite and/or hornblende and/or pyroxene; fine-grained equivalent of granodiorite and tonalite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Dacitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "dacite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Diabase
member.summary: Igneous rock of grain size intermediate between basalt and gabbro composed of plagioclase feldspar, pyroxene and opaque minerals. Synonym: dolerite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Diabasic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "diabase".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Diamictite
member.summary: Unsorted or poorly sorted, clastic sedimentary rock with a wide range of particle sizes including a muddy matrix. Biogenic materials that have such texture are excluded. Distinguished from conglomerate, sandstone, mudstone based on polymodality and lack of structures related to transport and deposition of sediment by moving air or water. If more than 10 percent of the fine grained matrix is of indeterminant clastic or diagenetic origin and the fabric is matrix supported, may also be categorized as wacke. Fairbridge and Bourgeois 1978.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Diamictitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "diamictite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Diatomaceous
member.summary: VARIANT. See "diatoms".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Diatoms
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles diatoms and/or diatom fragments.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Diorite
member.summary: Plutonic igneous rock consisting of plagioclase feldspar, commonly with hornblende and biotite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Dioritic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "diorite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Dioritoid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock with M less than 90, consisting of intermediate plagioclase, commonly with hornblende and often with biotite or augite. Plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is greater that 0.65, and anorthite content of plagioclase is less than 50 percent. Less than 10 percent feldspathoid mineral and less than 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 (and their subdivisions). LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Dioritoidic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "dioritoid".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.DoleriticRock
member.summary: Dark colored gabbroic (basaltic) or dioritic (andesitic) rock intermediate in grain size between basalt and gabbro and composed of plagioclase, pyroxene and opaque minerals; often with ophitic texture. Typically occurs as hypabyssal intrusions. Includes dolerite, microdiorite, diabase and microgabbro. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Dolomite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling a magnesium-rich carbonate mineral of calcium (CaMg(CO3)2).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.DolomiteConcretion
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology has rounded nodules of dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.DolomiteStringer
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains thin beds of dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Dolomitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "dolomite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Eclogite
member.summary: Metamorphic rock composed of 75 percent or more (by volume) omphacite and garnet, both of which are present as major constituents, the amount of neither of them being higher than 75 percent (by volume); the presence of plagioclase precludes classification as an eclogite. IUGS SCMR 2007

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Eclogitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "eclogite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.ExoticAlkalineRock
member.summary: Kimberlite, lamproite, or lamprophyre. Generally are potassic, mafic or ultramafic rocks. Olivine (commonly serpentinized in kimberlite), and phlogopite are significant constituents. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Feldspar
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling the rock-forming aluminosilicate minerals of sodium, potassium or calcium.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Feldsparic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "feldspar".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Feldspathic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "feldspar".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.FeldspathicArenite
member.summary: Clastic sandstone that contains less than 10 percent matrix. Matrix is mud-size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products) of detrital or diagenetic nature. Sandstones that contain less than 90 percent quartz.Dott, R. H, (1964). Wacke, Graywacke and matrix-what approach to immature sandstone classification: Journal of Sedimentary Petrology, v-34, p. 625-632.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Ferruginous
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling minerals rich in iron oxide or iron hydroxide.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.FineGrainedIgneousRock
member.summary: Undifferentaited Igneous rock in which the framework of the rock consists of crystals that are too small to determine mineralogy with the unaided eye; framework may include up to 50 percent glass. A significant percentage of the rock by volume may be phenocrysts. Includes rocks that are generally called volcanic rocks. Gillespie and Styles 1999; LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Fissile
member.summary: DEPRECATED. The term 'fissile' doesn't belong in this list as it is neither qualifier or modifier .... it is a descriptor of 'grain fabric'.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.FoidDioritoid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock in which M is less than 90, the plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is greater than 0.5, feldspathoid minerals form 10-60 percent of the QAPF fraction, plagioclase has anorthite content less than 50 percent. These rocks typically contain large amounts of mafic minerals. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 13 and 14. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.FoidGabbroid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock in which M is less than 90, the plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is greater than 0.5, feldspathoids form 10-60 percent of the QAPF fraction, and plagioclase has anorthite content greater than 50 percent. These rocks typically contain large amounts of mafic minerals. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 13 and 14. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.FoidSyenitoid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock with M less than 90, contains between 10 and 60 percent feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction, and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio less than 0.5. Includes QAPF fields 11 and 12. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Foidite
member.summary: Foiditoid that contains greater than 90 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Foiditic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "foidite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Foiditoid
member.summary: Fine grained crystalline rock containing less than 90 percent mafic minerals and more than 60 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 15 or chemically in TAS field F. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Foidolite
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline rock containing more than 60 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 15. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Foidolitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "foidolite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.FoliatedMetamorphicRock
member.summary: Metamorphic rock in which 10 percent or more of the contained mineral grains are elements in a planar or linear fabric. Cataclastic or glassy character precludes classification with this concept. Based on NADM SLTT metamorphic.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Foraminifera
member.summary: VARIANT. See "forams".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Foraminiferous
member.summary: VARIANT. See "forams".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Forams
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains marine micro-organisms of the order Foraminifera (Devonian - Recent), having a calcareous shell.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.ForamsUndifferentiated
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See forams.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.FossilFragment
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "fossil fragments".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.FossilFragments
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains material comprised of fossils or fossil fragments.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Fossiliferous
member.summary: VARIANT. See "fossil fragments".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.FossilsUndifferentiated
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains material comprised of fossils or fossil fragments of undetermined type type, form or species.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.FragmentalIgneousRock
member.summary: Igneous rock in which greater than 75 percent of the rock consists of fragments produced as a result of igneous rock-forming process. Includes pyroclastic rocks, autobreccia associated with lava flows and intrusive breccias. Excludes deposits reworked by epiclastic processes (see Tuffite).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gabbro
member.summary: Gabbroic rock that contains between 0 and 5 percent quartz and no feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF Field 10 as gabbro. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gabbroic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "gabbro".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.GabbroicRock
member.summary: Gabbroid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.9 in the QAPF fraction. Includes QAPF fields 10*, 10, and 10'. This category includes the various categories defined in LeMaitre et al. (2002) based on the mafic mineralogy, but apparently not subdivided based on the quartz/feldspathoid content. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gabbroid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock that contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, and up to 20 percent quartz or up to 10 percent feldspathoid in the QAPF fraction. The ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is greater than 0.65, and anorthite content of the plagioclase is greater than 50 percent. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 and their subdivisions. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gabbroidic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "gabbroid".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gilsonite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains material containing or resembling gilsonite (uintaite), a brilliant black variety of asphalt occurring in rounded masses.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gilsonitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "gilsonite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Glauconite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling the generally greenish authogenic clay mineral glauconite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Glauconitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "glauconite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gneiss
member.summary: Foliated metamorphic rock with bands or lenticles rich in granular minerals alternating with bands or lenticles rich in minerals with a flaky or elongate prismatic habit. Mylonitic foliation or well developed, continuous schistosity (greater than 50 percent of the rock consists of grains participate in a planar or linear fabric) precludes classification with this concept. Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gneissic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "gneiss".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Granite
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline rock consisting of quartz, alkali feldspar and plagioclase (typically sodic) in variable amounts, usually with biotite and/or hornblende. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF Field 3. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Granitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "granite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Granodiorite
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline rock consisting essentially of quartz, sodic plagioclase and lesser amounts of alkali feldspar with minor hornblende and biotite. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 4. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Granodioritic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "granodiorite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Granofels
member.summary: Metamorphic rock with granoblastic fabric and very little or no foliation (less than 10 percent of the mineral grains in the rock are elements in a planar or linear fabric). Grainsize not specified. SLTTm 2004.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Granulite
member.summary: Metamorphic rock of high metamorphic grade in which Fe-Mg silicate minerals are dominantly hydroxl-free; feldspar must be present, and muscovite is absent; rock contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, less than 75 percent calcite and/or dolomite, less than 75 percent quartz, less than 50 percent iron-bearing minerals (hematite, magnetite, limonite-group, siderite, iron-sulfides), and less than 50 percent calc-silicate minerals. Fettes and Desmons (2007). See also Wimmenauer (1985), Winkler (1979) (D.R. Bowes (1989), The Encyclopedia of Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology; Van Nostrand Reinhold ISBN: 0-442-20623-2

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Granulitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "granulite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gravel
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains particles in the size range of 2mm - 20mm.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gravelly
member.summary: VARIANT. See "gravel".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Greenstone
member.summary: Chlorite actinolite epidote metamorphic rocks. Metamorphic rock characterized by 50 percent or more of combined chlorite, actinolite and epidote. Category for rocks generally named greenschist or greenstone. OneGeology, simplified for WITSML to Greenstone.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gumbo
member.summary: A term used in the U.S. for clay soils that become sticky, impervious, and plastic when wet.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gypsiferous
member.summary: VARIANT. See "gypsum".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Gypsum
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling the evaporite mineral gypsum (CaSO4.2H2O).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Halite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles the common evaporite mineral Halite (NaCl).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Halitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "halite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Hornfels
member.summary: Granofels formed by contact metamorphism, composed of a mosaic of equidimensional grains in a characteristically granoblastic or decussate matrix; porphyroblasts or relict phenocrysts may be present. Typically fine grained.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Hornfelsic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "hornfels".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Igneous
member.summary: VARIANT. See "igneous rock".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.IgneousRock
member.summary: Undefined rock formed as a result of igneous processes, for example intrusion and cooling of magma in the crust, or volcanic eruption. Neuendorf et al 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Illite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling the common clay mineral illite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Illitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "illite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.ImpactGeneratedMaterial
member.summary: Material that contains features indicative of shock metamorphism, such as microscopic planar deformation features within grains or shatter cones, interpreted to be the result of extraterrestrial bolide impact. Includes breccias and melt rocks. Stffler and Grieve 2007; Jackson 1997.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.ImpureDolomite
member.summary: Impure carbonate sedimentary rock with a ratio of magnesium carbonate to calcite (plus aragonite) greater than 1 to 1. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.ImpureLimestone
member.summary: Impure carbonate sedimentary rock with a calcite (plus aragonite) to dolomite ratio greater than 1 to 1. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.IntrusiveRockPlutonic
member.summary: Igneous rock formed by cooling and solidification of magma within the earth's crust.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.IronRichSedimentaryRock
member.summary: Sedimentary rock that consists of at least 50 percent iron-bearing minerals (hematite, magnetite, limonite-group, siderite, iron-sulfides), as determined by hand-lens or petrographic analysis. Corresponds to a rock typically containing 15 percent iron by weight. Hallsworth and Knox 1999; SLTTs 2004.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.KalsiliticAndMeliliticRocks
member.summary: Igneous rock containing greater than 10 percent melilite or kalsilite. Typically undersaturated, ultrapotassic (kalsilitic rocks) or calcium-rich (melilitic rocks) mafic or ultramafic rocks. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Kaolinite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling the common clay mineral kaolinite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Kaolinitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "kaolinite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.KomatiiticRock
member.summary: Ultramafic, magnesium-rich volcanic rock, typically with spinifex texture of intergrown skeletal and bladed olivine and pyroxene crystals set in abundant glass. Includes komatiite and meimechite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LatiticRock
member.summary: Trachytoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.35 and 0.65. QAPF fields 8, 8' and 8*. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Lignite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling a soft brownish-black form of coal.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Lignitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "lignite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LimeBoundstone
member.summary: Biogenic textural class. The origianl components were bound and encrusted together by the action of plants and animals in the position of growth. That is, Reef limestones. Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LimeFramestone
member.summary: Biogenic textural class. Carbonate reef rock consisting of a rigid framework of colonies, shells or skeletons, with internal cavities filled with fine sediment; usually created through the activities of colonial organisms. Source () Hallsworth & Knox 1999; SLTTs 2004, Table 15-3-1

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LimeGrainstone
member.summary: Depositional textural cassification. Grain supported carbonate with little ( less than 25 percent) carbonate matrix. Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LimeMudstone
member.summary: Depositional textural cassification. Original components not bound together during deposition. Contains mud (clay and fine silt-size carbonate). Mud-supported (particles greater than 20 mm). Less than 10 percent Grains. Mudstone that contains between 10 and 50 percent carbonate minerals in the mud size fraction. Carbonate origin is not specified. The operational test typically used to identify this category is if the rock fizzes when hydrochloric acid is applied. The '10 percent carbonate' criteria is a fuzzy boundary.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LimePackstone
member.summary: Grain supported carbonate. Original components not bound together during deposition. Contains mud (clay and fine silt-size carbonate). Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LimeWackestone
member.summary: Depositional textural cassification. Original components not bound together during deposition. Matrix supported. Contains less than 75 percent mud grade (less than 32 micrometer) calcite. (clay and fine silt-size carbonate). Mud-supported (particles greater than 20 mm). Greater than 10 percent Grains. Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Limestone
member.summary: Pure carbonate sedimentary rock with a calcite (plus aragonite) to dolomite ratio greater than 1 to 1. Includes limestone and dolomitic limestone. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LimestoneStringer
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains thin beds of limestone.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LimestoneArgillaceous
member.summary: A limestone homogeneously mixed with 10-50% clay minerals.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LimestoneDolomitic
member.summary: A limestone containing 10-50% dolomite and 50-90% calcite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LimestoneSandy
member.summary: A limestone homogeneously mixed with 10-50% quartz grains.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Lithic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "lithic fragments".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LithicFragment
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "lithic fragments".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.LithicFragments
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of undetermined rock fragments.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Marble
member.summary: Metamorphic rock consisting of greater than 75 percent fine- to coarse-grained recrystallized calcite and/or dolomite; usually with a granoblastic, saccharoidal texture. IUGS SCMR 2007

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Marcasite
member.summary: Indicates that the associate lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of the white (gem) form of iron pyrites (FeS).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Marcasitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "marcasite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Marl
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of a crumbly mixture of clays, calcium and magnesium carbonates.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Marly
member.summary: VARIANT. See "marl".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.MetamorphicRock
member.summary: Undefined rock formed by solid-state mineralogical, chemical and/or structural changes to a pre-existing rock, in response to marked changes in temperature, pressure, shearing stress and chemical environment. Not further defined. Jackson 1997.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Mica
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of mica, a group of hydrous aluminosilicate minerals that split easily into thin partly-transparent sheets.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.MicaSchist
member.summary: A schist that consists of more than 50 percent mica minerals, typically muscovite or biotite. Special type included to distinguish this common variety of schist. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Micaceous
member.summary: VARIANT. See "mica".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Microfossil
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See microfossils.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Microfossiliferous
member.summary: VARIANT. See "microfossils".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Microfossils
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains undifferentiated microscopic fossils.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Migmatite
member.summary: Silicate metamorphic rock that is pervasively heterogeneous on a decimeter to meter scale that typically consists of darker and lighter parts; the darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks whereas the lighter parts are of igneous-looking appearance. Fette and Desmons (2007)

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Migmatitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "migmatite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Monzogabbro
member.summary: Monzogabbroic rock that contains between 0 an 5 percent quartz and no feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 9. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Monzogabbroic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "monzogabbro".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Mud
member.summary: Clastic sediment consisting of less than 30 percent gravel-size (2 mm) particles and with a mud-size to sand-size particle ratio greater than 1. More than half of the particles are of epiclastic origin. Definition of mud from SLTTs 2004 muddy sediment; particle sizes defined from Krumbein phi scale (W C Krumbein & L L Sloss, Stratigraphy and Sedimentation, 2nd edition, Freeman, San Francisco, 1963; Krumbein and Pettijohn, 1938, Manual of Sedimentary Petrography: New York, Appleton Century Co., Inc.).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Muddy
member.summary: VARIANT. See "mud".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Mudstone
member.summary: Clastic sedimentary rock consisting of less than 30 percent gravel-size (2 mm) particles and with a mud to sand ratio greater than 1. The definition includes Claystone, Siltstone and Shale. Pettijohn et al. 1987 referenced in Hallsworth & Knox 1999; extrapolated from Folk, 1954, Figure 1a.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.MyloniticRock
member.summary: Metamorphic rock characterised by a foliation resulting from tectonic grain size reduction, in which more than 10 percent of the rock volume has undergone grain size reduction. Includes protomylonite, mylonite, ultramylonite, and blastomylonite. Marshak & Mitra 1988.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.NoDescription
member.summary: DEPRECATED. Where's the validity of creating a null entry for either qualifier or modifer?.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.NoSample
member.summary: A sample would be expected, given the drilling situation, but nothing was seen at the shakers, implying either solution in the mud system of a salt, or lack of returns. WITSML.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.None
member.summary: DEPRECATED. Where's the validity of creating a null entry for either qualifier or modifer?.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Oncolite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology is largely composed of oncoliths (oncoids).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Oncolith
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See oncoliths.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Oncolithic
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See oncoliths.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Oncoliths
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of oncoliths (oncoids), a type of carbonate-coated grain with irregular laminae.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Oncolitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "oncoliths".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.OoidOrOolith
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See ooids.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Ooids
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of ooids (ooliths), small round grains consisting of calcium carbonate, silica, or dolomite.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Ooliths
member.summary: VARIANT. See "ooids".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Oolitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "ooids".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Ooze
member.summary: Biogenic sediment consisting of less than 1 percent gravel-size (greater than or equal to 2 mm) particles, with a sand to mud ratio less than 1 to 9, and less than 50 percent carbonate minerals. Based on Bates and Jackson 1987 & Hallsworth & Knox 1999.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Ophiolite
member.summary: Basic and ultra-basic igneous rocks and their metamorposed, often hydrated, derivatives, believed to represent former oceanic crust.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Ophiolitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "ophiolite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.OrganicBearingMudstone
member.summary: Mudstone that contains a significant amount of organic carbon, typically kerogen. Commonly finely laminated, brown or black in color. Neuendorf et al. 2005;

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Ostracodal
member.summary: VARIANT. See "ostracods".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Ostracods
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling ostracod (Cambrian - Recent) fossils.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Peat
member.summary: Unconsolidated organic-rich sediment composed of at least 50 percent semi-carbonised plant remains; individual remains commonly seen with unaided eye; yellowish brown to brownish black; generally fibrous texture; can be plastic or friable. In its natural state it can be readily cut and has a very high moisture content, generally greater than 90 percent. Liptinite to Inertinite ratio is less than one (Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.). Hallsworth & Knox 1999.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Peaty
member.summary: VARIANT. See "peat".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pebble
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains rounded rock fragments in the size range of 2mm - 64mm.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pebbly
member.summary: VARIANT. See "pebble".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pegmatite
member.summary: Exceptionally coarse grained crystalline rock with interlocking crystals; most grains are 1 centimeter or more diameter; composition is generally that of granite, but the term may refer to the coarse grained facies of any type of igneous rock; usually found as irregular dikes, lenses, or veins associated with plutons or batholiths. Neuendorf et al 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pegmatitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "pegmatite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pellet
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See pellets.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pelletal
member.summary: VARIANT. See "pellets".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pellets
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or is characteristic of small ovoid or spherical particles of microcrystalline calcite, in the size range 0.03mm - 0.15mm.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Peloid
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See peloids.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Peloidal
member.summary: VARIANT. See "peloids".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Peloids
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or is characteristic of sand-size grains of carbonate mud.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Peridotite
member.summary: Ultramafic rock consisting of more than 40 percent (by volume) olivine with pyroxene and/or amphibole and little or no feldspar. Commonly altered to serpentinite. Includes rocks defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification as dunite, harzburgite, lherzolite, wehrlite, olivinite, pyroxene peridotite, pyroxene hornblende peridotite or hornblende peridotite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Peridotitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "peridotite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.PhaneriticIgneousRock
member.summary: Igneous rock in which the framework of the rock consists of individual crystals that can be discerned with the unaided eye. Bounding grain size is on the order of 32 to 100 microns. Igneous rocks with 'exotic' composition are excluded from this concept. Neuendorf et al 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Phonolite
member.summary: Phonolitoid in which the plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is less than 0.1. Rock consists of alkali feldspar, feldspathoid minerals, and mafic minerals. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Phonolitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "phonolite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Phonolitoid
member.summary: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 10 and 60 percent feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio less than 0.5. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 11 and 12, and TAS field Ph. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Phosphate
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains phosphates.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.PhosphateRock
member.summary: Any rock containing phosphate minerals such as apatite of sufficient purity and abundance to be an economic resource.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Phosphatic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "phosphate".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Phyllite
member.summary: Rock with a well developed, continuous schistosity, an average grain size between 0.1 and 0.5 millimeters, and a silvery sheen on cleavage surfaces. Individual phyllosilicate grains are barely visible with the unaided eye. IUGS SCMR 2007.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Phyllitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "phyllite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pisolite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology is composed largely of pisoliths (pisoids).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pisolith
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See pisoliths.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pisoliths
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or is characteristic of sub-spherical usually carbonate coated grains, of diameter greater than 2mm.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pisolitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "pisolite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.PlantRemains
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains remains of a probable botanical origin.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Porphyritic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "porphyry".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Porphyry
member.summary: Igneous rock that contains conspicuous phenocrysts in a finer grained groundmass; groundmass itself may be phaneritic or fine-grained. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.PotassiumAndMagnesiumSalts
member.summary: Evaporite composed with significant (greater than 50 percent) magnesium salts, such as Carnallite /Kainite/Polyhalite/Kieserite/Bischofite/Tachydrite. WITSML.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pyrite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling the sulphide mineral of iron (FeS2).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pyritic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "pyrite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.PyroclasticBreccia
member.summary: Pyroclastic rock in which greater than 25 percent of particles are greater than 64 millimeter in largest dimension. Includes agglomerate, pyroclastic breccia of Gillespie and Styles (1999). Schmid 1981; LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.PyroclasticRock
member.summary: Fragmental igneous rock that consists of greater than 75 percent fragments produced as a direct result of eruption or extrusion of magma from within the earth onto its surface. Includes autobreccia associated with lava flows and excludes deposits reworked by epiclastic processes. Based on LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pyroxenite
member.summary: Ultramafic phaneritic igneous rock composed almost entirely of one or more pyroxenes and occasionally biotite, hornblende and olivine. Includes rocks defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification as olivine pyroxenite, olivine-hornblende pyroxenite, pyroxenite, orthopyroxenite, clinopyroxenite and websterite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Pyroxenitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "pyroxenite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Quartiferous
member.summary: VARIANT. See "quartz".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Quartz
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (crystalline) material containing or resembling the common silica mineral quartz (SiO2).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.QuartzArenite
member.summary: Clastic sandstone that contains less than 10 percent matrix. Matrix is mud-size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products) of detrital or diagenetic nature. Sandstones that contain more than 90 percent of siliceous grains. Grains can include quartz or chert rock fragments. Dott, R. H, (1964). Wacke, Graywacke and matrix-what approach to immature sandstone classification: Journal of Sedimentary Petrology, v-34, p. 625-632.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Quartzite
member.summary: Metamorphic rock consisting of greater than or equal to 75 percent quartz; typically granoblastic texture. Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Quartzitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "quartzite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Radiolaria
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling fossils of the marine protozoan order of Radiolaria (Cambrian - Recent), generally with endoskeletons of opaline silica.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Radiolarian
member.summary: VARIANT. See "radiolaria".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Rhyolite
member.summary: rhyolitoid in which the ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is between 0.1 and 0.65. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Rhyolitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "rhyolite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.RockSalt
member.summary: Evaporite composed of at least 50 percent halite. Superset of Halite, Silvite and Potassium and magnesium salts. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Rootlets
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling plant roots, or structures (rhizoliths) resulting from the mineralization of plant roots by accumulation/cementation or replacement.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Salty
member.summary: VARIANT. See "rock salt".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Sand
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (crystalline) material containing or resembling mineral or rock grains of diameter in the range of 0.625mm - 2mm.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Sandstone
member.summary: Clastic sedimentary rock in which less than 30 percent of particles are greater than 2 millimeter in diameter (gravel) and the sand to mud ratio is at least 1. SLTTs 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005; particle size from Wentworth grade scale.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Sandy
member.summary: VARIANT. See "sand".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Sapropel
member.summary: Jelly like organic rich sediment composed of plant remains, usually algal. Liptinite to Inertinite ratio is greater than one (Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.). Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Sapropelic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "sapropel".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Schist
member.summary: Foliated phaneritic metamorphic rock with well developed, continuous schistosity, meaning that greater than 50 percent of the rock by volume is mineral grains with a thin tabular, lamellar, or acicular prismatic crystallographic habit that are oriented in a continuous planar or linear fabric. SLTTm 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Schisty
member.summary: VARIANT. See "schist".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Sepentinitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "serpentinite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Serpentinite
member.summary: Rock consisting of more than 75 percent serpentine-group minerals, eg. antigorite, chrysotile or lizardite; accessory chlorite, talc and magnetite may be present; derived from hydration of ferromagnesian silicate minerals such as olivine and pyroxene. Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Shale
member.summary: Laminated mudstone that will part or break along thin, closely spaced layers parallel to stratification. NADM SLTT sedimentary, 2004. WITSML note: Since Hallsworth and Knox did not recognise the term Shale, some operators do not use this in descriptions, but do plot it graphically.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Shaly
member.summary: VARIANT. See "shale".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Shell
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See "shell fragments".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.ShellFragments
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling shells (generally bivalves) or fragments thereof.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Shelly
member.summary: VARIANT. See "shell fragments".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Siderite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling siderite (spathic iron), a carbonate mineral of iron (FeCO3).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.SideriteConcretion
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology contains rounded masses comprised of the mineral siderite (spathic iron), a carbonate mineral of iron (FeCO3).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Sideritic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "siderite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.SiliceousOoze
member.summary: Ooze that consists of more than 50 percent siliceous skeletal remains. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Silt
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material of very fine particles intermediate in size between clay and sand (0.0625mm - 2mm).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Siltstone
member.summary: Mudstone that contains detectable silt. OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Silty
member.summary: VARIANT. See "silt".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Skarn
member.summary: Metasomatic rock consisting mainly of Ca-, Mg-, Fe-, or Mn-silicate minerals, which are free from or poor in water. Typically formed at the contact between a silicate rock or magma and a carbonate rock.Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p195.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Skarny
member.summary: VARIANT. See "skarn".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Slate
member.summary: Compact, fine grained rock with an average grain size less than 0.032 millimeter and a well developed schistosity (slaty cleavage), and hence can be split into slabs or thin plates. NADM metamorphic rock vocabulary SLTTm1.0; Neuendorf et al. 2005.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Slaty
member.summary: VARIANT. See "slate".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Smectite
member.summary: A matrix cement dominantly composed of Smectite. Chemically Smectite is a hydrated sodium calcium aluminium magnesium silicate hydroxide (Na,Ca)0.33(Al,Mg)2(Si4O10)(OH)2nH2O. It will respond to changes in hydration, so may be altered in cuttings samples.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Smectitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "smectite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Spicular
member.summary: VARIANT. See "spicules".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Spicule
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See spicules.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Spicules
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling minute needle-like structures of silica or carbonate, such as that supporting the soft tissue of certain invertebrates, especially sponges.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Spilite
member.summary: Altered basic to intermediate composition fine-grained igneous rock in which the feldspar is partially or completely composed of of albite, typically accompanied by chlorite, calcite, quartz, epidote, prehnite, and low-temperature hydrous crystallization products. Preservation of eruptive volcanic features is typical. Fettes and Desmon, 2007; Best, M.G., 1982, Igneous and metamorphic petrology: New York, W.H. Freeman and Company, p. 398; Neuendorf et al. 2005, p. 619.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Spilitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "spilite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Stylolite
member.summary: DEPRECATED. See stylolites.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Stylolites
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling a contact zone surface between two adjacent calcareous rocks, along which dissolution by pressure solution has ocurred and appearing in cross section as a series of jagged interlocking up-and-down projections (of insoluble clay minerals) that resemble a suture.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Stylolitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "stylolites".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Syenite
member.summary: Plutonic igneous rock composed essentially of alkali feldspar, with lesser sodic plagioclase, biotite and hornblende, and minor quartz.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Syenitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "syenite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Syenitoid
member.summary: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock with M less than 90, consisting mainly of alkali feldspar and plagioclase; minor quartz or nepheline may be present, along with pyroxene, amphibole or biotite. Ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is less than 0.65, quartz forms less than 20 percent of QAPF fraction, and feldspathoid minerals form less than 10 percent of QAPF fraction. Includes rocks classified in QAPF fields 6, 7 and 8 and their subdivisions. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Sylvite
member.summary: Evaporite composed of at least 50 percent Sylvite (KCL). OneGeology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Sylvitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "sylvite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Tarry
member.summary: VARIANT. See "bitumen".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Tephrite
member.summary: Tephritoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.9, and contains less than 10 percent normative (CIPW) olivine. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Tephritic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "tephrite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Tephritoid
member.summary: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 10 and 60 percent feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.5. Includes rocks classified in QAPF field 13 and 14 or chemically in TAS field U1 as basanite or tephrite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.TholeiiticBasalt
member.summary: Tholeiitic basalt is defined here to contain 2 pyroxene phases and interstitial quartz or tridymite or cristobalite in the groundmass. Pyroxene (augite and orthopyroxene or pigeonite) and calcium-rich plagioclase are common phenocryst minerals. Olivine may also be a phenocryst, and when present, may have rims of pigeonite. Only in tholeiitic basalt is olivine in reaction relationship with melt. Interstitial siliceous residue may be present, and is often glassy. Tholeiitic basalt is relatively poor in sodium. This category includes most basalts of the ocean floor, most large oceanic islands, and continental flood basalts such as the Columbia River Plateau.Carmichael, I.S. Turner, F.J., Verhoogen, John, 1974, Igneous petrology: New York, McGraw HIll Book Co., p.42-43.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Tonalite
member.summary: Granitoid consisting of quartz and intermediate plagioclase, usually with biotite and amphibole. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 5; ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is greater than 0.9. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Tonalitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "tonalite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Trachyte
member.summary: A group of fine-grained often porphyritic volcanic rocks containing alkali feldspar and minor mafic minerals.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Trachytic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "trachyte".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.TrachyticRock
member.summary: Trachytoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.1 and 0.35. QAPF fields 7, 7', and 7*. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Trachytoid
member.summary: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, less than 10 percent feldspathoid mineral and less than 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio less than 0.65. Mafic minerals typically include amphibole or mica; typically porphyritic. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 6, 7 and 8 (with subdivisions) or chemically in TAS Field T as trachyte or latite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Travertine
member.summary: Biotically or abiotically precipitated calcium carbonate, from spring-fed, heated, or ambient-temperature water. May be white and spongy, various shades of orange, tan or gray, and ranges to dense, banded or laminated rock. Macrophytes, bryophytes, algae, cyanobacteria and other organisms often colonize the surface of travertine and may be preserved, to produce the porous varieties. Neuendorf et al. 2005; Chafetz, H.S., and Folk, R.L., 1984, Travertine: Depositional morphology an dthe bacterially constructed constituents: J. Sed. Petrology, v. 126, p.57-74.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Tuff
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling pyroclastic detrital material (volcanic ash).

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Tuffaceous
member.summary: VARIANT. See "tuff".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Tuffite
member.summary: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling a fine grained matrix of volcanic breccia with intruded grains of fluidized sediment.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Tuffitic
member.summary: VARIANT. See "tuffite".

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Ultrabasic
member.summary: A class of igneous rocks composed mostly of mafic minerals such as pyroxenes along with calcic feldspar, with no free silica and a total silica content less than about 45%.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Undifferentiated
member.summary: The lithology is not differentiated. This is typically used to fill out a lithology description to 100 percent.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Wacke
member.summary: Clastic sandstone with more than 10 percent matrix of indeterminate detrital or diagenetic nature. Matrix is mud size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products). Pettijohn, Potter, Siever, 1972, Sand and Sandstone: New York, Springer Verlag, 681 p.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.QualifierType.Unknown
member.summary: The value is not known. This value should not be used in normal situations. All reasonable attempts should be made to determine the appropriate value. Use of this value may result in rejection in some situations.

member.name: T:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm
member.summary: The type of algorithm used in the calculation of a trajectory station dependent data. This is traditionally positional information except for the cases of inertial survey data. See API Bulletin D20 "BULLETIN ON DIRECTIONAL DRILLING SURVEY CALCULATION METHODS AND TERMINOLOGY", First Edition December 31, 1985.

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.#ctor
member.summary: Protected constructor, should always pass in "name"

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor

member.name: M:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.GetList
member.summary: Retrieves the complete list of TrajStnCalcAlgorithms

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.ConstantToolFace
member.summary: An algorithm used to design a well trajectory during the planning stage

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.MinimumCurvature
member.summary: An algorithm used to calculate the well trajectory spatial position (X,Y,Z) at execution stage or planning stage. The assumed path between stations is that of a circular arc in 3-D space. Also known as "Minimum Radius Of Curvature" method.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.Tangential
member.summary: An algorithm used to calculate the well trajectory spatial position (X,Y,Z) at execution stage or planning stage. The assumed path between stations is a straight line oriented according to the seconds stations orientation. Also known as "Backward Station" and "Terminal Angle" methods.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.BalancedTangential
member.summary: An algorithm used to calculate the well trajectory spatial position (X,Y,Z) at execution stage or planning stage. The assumed path between stations is along two straight lines, with the first section oriented according to the first stations orientation and the second line oriented according to the second stations orientation. Each line segment is set to have a length of half the measured depth difference between the two stations. Also known as "Acceleration", "Secant", "Trapezoidal", and "Vector Averaging" methods.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.AverageAngle
member.summary: An algorithm used to calculate the well trajectory spatial position (X,Y,Z) at execution stage or planning stage. The assumed path between stations is along a straight line oriented according to the average of the inclination and azimuth orientations of the start and end stations. Also known as "Angle Averaging" method.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.RadiusOfCurvature
member.summary: An algorithm used to calculate the well trajectory spatial position (X,Y,Z) at execution stage or planning stage. The assumed path is a helix with a fixed vertical radius wrapped around a cylinder of fixed radius. Both radii can tend to infinity yielding simple circular arcs in either the horizontal or vertical planes.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.Inertial
member.summary: This encompasses surveying methods where the positional data was not derived from a transformation of MD,INC,AZM, but are provided directly by some other mechanism such as direct positional output from an inertial gyro system.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.Custom
member.summary: This encompasses methodologies which are similar to the Inertial method in that they are direct populations of the positional data, which have been determined by some other possibly non-published methodology.

member.name: P:Energistics.DataAccess.WITSML141.TrajStnCalcAlgorithm.Unknown
member.summary: The value is not known. This value should not be used in normal situations. All reasonable attempts should be made to determine the appropriate value. Use of this value may result in rejection in some situations.

member.summary: Information about the XML message instance.
